item.title: Commerce Halts as Kenya Police Barricade Capital From Protesters
item.description: The streets of downtown Nairobi were deserted and many store fronts were soldered shut as workers and traders stayed away on fears that protests demanding the removal of President William Ruto may turn violent.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks, David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man walks past a barbed wire barricade set up by police outside parliament ahead of possible Saba Saba Day demonstrations in Nairobi on July 7, 2025. Kenya marked its fight for democracy on July 7, 2025 with police blocking main roads in Nairobi ahead of potential protests, after last month's demonstrations descended into violent clashes. Saba Saba Day marks the uprising on July 7, 1990 when Kenyans demanded a return to multi-party democracy after years of autocratic rule by then-president Daniel arap Moi. (Photo by Tony KARUMBA / AFP) (Photo by TONY KARUMBA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: BRICS Is Getting Increasingly Hard to Ignore
item.description: Expansion of the club to include 10 members is enhancing its economic clout in a US-dominated world.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin is seen projected on a screen during the first plenary session of the BRICS summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on July 6, 2025. Photographer: Mauro Pimentel/AFP

item.title: Trump Warns of 10% Tariff for ‘Anti-American’ BRICS Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would put an additional 10% tariff on any country aligning themselves with “the Anti-American policies of BRICS,” injecting further uncertainty into global trade as the US continues to negotiate levies with many trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Will Oliver/EPA

item.title: Portugal Sees EU, US Reaching Deal With ‘Very Low’ Tariffs
item.description: Portuguese Finance Minister Joaquim Miranda Sarmento said he sees the European Union and the US reaching an agreement with tariffs potentially below 10% that would help keep trade flowing.
item.dc:creator: Francine Lacqua, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Joaquim Miranda Sarmento on July 7. Photographer: Omar Havana/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Retaliation to EU Curbs Clouds Ties Before Summit
item.description: China hit back at the European Union’s restrictions on its medical device makers while maintaining key exceptions, adding uncertainty to ties ahead of a high-stakes summit later this month.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Amber Tong

item.title: Mexico’s Next Top Judge Says Company Taxes Should Be Clear Cut
item.description: As Mexican courts embrace a new era following the nation’s first-ever election of judges, the Supreme Court’s incoming chief says one of his priorities will be to ensure fairness across the board — and that includes company tax obligations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Hugo Aguilar Ortiz at his office in Mexico City, on June 30.

item.title: Ramaphosa Ally Accused of Sabotaging South African Murder Probe
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa faces a fresh crisis within his government after a senior police official accused one of his ministers of interference in an investigation into political assassinations.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a news conference following a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy became the fist leader of Ukraine to visit South Africa in a bid to expand diplomatic outreach while he can no longer fully rely on US as his nation’s key ally and the peace deal with Russia remains elusive.

item.title: Thailand Backtracks on Casino as Political Turmoil Deepens
item.description: Thailand’s government will withdraw a controversial bill to legalize casinos from parliament following mounting public opposition and a fresh bout of political turmoil that has reduced the ruling coalition’s majority.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: A roulette wheel.

item.title: Zelenskiy Spoke With Trump About Replacing Ukraine’s Envoy to US
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy discussed replacing the current ambassador to the US during his phone call with President Donald Trump on Friday, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: UNITED STATES - SEPTEMBER 21: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukrainian Ambassador to the U.S. Oksana Markarova, right, leave a meeting with House members in the U.S. Capitol en route to a meeting with senators on Thursday, September 21, 2023. item.title: Philippines’ Marcos Open to Limiting, Taxing Online Gambling
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. will not oppose proposals to limit and tax online gambling amid a boom that’s boosted gaming revenue but has also raised concern among officials and lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

item.title: Trump Slams Musk Plan for Rival Party as Feud Deepens
item.description: President Donald Trump blasted Elon Musk’s bid to start a new political party, intensifying a feud between former allies and deepening investors’ concerns about implications for Tesla Inc. and other companies led by the world’s richest man.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images)

item.title: Turkey Ramps Up Opposition Probes, Keeping Markets on Edge
item.description: Turkey launched an investigation into the main opposition party’s leader and arrested more of its mayors, in a widening crackdown that’s likely to stoke investor anxiety over risks to the rule of law and political stability.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: Ozgur Ozel, leader of Turkey's main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), gives a speech during an extraordinary congress of the party in Ankara on April 6, 2025. Until now the relatively low-profile head of the CHP, Ozel is expected to be re-elected after ten days of protests sparked by the arrest of its kingpin, the mayor of Istanbul. (Photo by Adem ALTAN / AFP) (Photo by ADEM ALTAN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Deadly Floods Reinforce Texas’ Challenge as Crisis Epicenter
item.description: Before dawn Friday morning, city manager Dalton Rice went for a jog along the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas. He finished his run around 4 a.m. as a light rain set in. An hour later, he began receiving emergency calls: The river had flooded out of control.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan, Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Joe Lovinger, Mary Hui

item.title: UK Business ‘Struggling to See’ What’s Pro-Business About Labour
item.description: Before taking office last July, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves met business leaders over a series of breakfasts that became known as the smoked salmon and scrambled eggs offensive. British bosses were clamoring for change after 14 years of rule by the opposition Conservative party, and her pitch went down well.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Nimmo, Irina Anghel, Jennifer Creery

media:content.media:description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves and Prime Minister Keir Starmer in London, in July.

item.title: Thailand Offers US More Trade Concessions to Avert 36% Levy
item.description: Thailand is making a last-ditch effort to avert a punitive 36% export levy threatened by the Trump administration with offers of greater market access for US farm and industrial goods, along with increased purchases of energy and Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes next to shipping containers at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to announce export figures on Jan. 31.

item.title: Italy’s Bridge to Nowhere Shows Defense-Boom Risks
item.description: The era of greenwashing is giving way to defense-washing. It won’t make Europe stronger.
item.dc:creator: Lionel Laurent

media:content.media:description: A protest in Messina, Italy, on May 30, 2025, against the construction of the bridge over the Strait of Messina.

item.title: Nations Chase US Trade Deals as Bessent Hints at Extension
item.description: Major US trading partners hurried over the weekend to secure trade deals or lobby for extra time, while Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent indicated that some countries lacking an agreement by the deadline Wednesday will have the option of a three-week extension to negotiate.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Japan’s Real Wages Fall Most Since 2023 in Headache for Ishiba
item.description: Japanese workers’ real wages dropped by the most since September 2023 as inflation continued to outpace salary growth, posing a growing problem for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba ahead of a key election taking place in about two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Starmer Seeks to Hold Line on Spending After Defeat on Welfare
item.description: The UK government talked down hopes that the two-child cap on parental benefits might be scrapped, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to hold the line on spending after failing to push through separate controversial welfare cuts.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Ship Hit in Red Sea as Israel Strikes Houthi-Controlled Ports
item.description: Multiple small vessels attacked a ship in the Red Sea near Yemen’s Al Hudaydah port, causing a fire on board and prompting the crew to abandon ship before the Israel army carried out airstrikes on Houthi-controlled ports in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: Sara Gharaibeh, Sherif Tarek

item.title: Polish Border Checks Start as Migration Piles Pressure on Tusk
item.description: Checks by Poland at its borders with Germany and Lithuania started on Monday in a retaliatory move by Prime Minister Donald Tusk against recent actions by Berlin aimed at curbing irregular migration.
item.dc:creator: Maciej Martewicz

media:content.media:description: Polish police officers stand at the German-Polish border crossing between Brandenburg, Germany and Slubice, Poland on July 5.

item.title: Lutnick Says Trump’s Tariffs Will Take Effect on Aug. 1
item.description: President Donald Trump’s country-by-country tariffs will take effect Aug. 1, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said, signaling some breathing room for US trading partners ahead of a July 9 deadline previously set by the president.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick speaks to members of the media before boarding Air Force One with US President Donald Trump at Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, on July 6, 2025.

item.title: Decade-Old Local Currency Push by BRICS Is Still a Pipe Dream
item.description: BRICS countries once again failed to make significant strides in the cross-border payments system for trade and investment they’ve been discussing for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: A plenary session at the BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro on July 6.

item.title: Russia, Iran Relegated to the Periphery as Awkward BRICS Guests
item.description: Unlike Brazil’s Group of 20 summit, no one was late or missing when leaders of the world’s major emerging-market nations gathered for a family photo Sunday in Rio de Janeiro — at least not accidentally.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy, Simone Iglesias

item.title: Petro Confidant Says She’s Out of Colombia’s Government for Good
item.description: Colombia’s outgoing foreign minister, a key lieutenant who was seen as a moderating influence on President Gustavo Petro, says her time in government is now over.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Wicary

media:content.media:description: Laura Sarabia at her office in Bogota, Colombia, on March 5.

item.title: ICE Raids Derail Los Angeles Economy as Workers Go Into Hiding
item.description: Los Angeles was already struggling to revive its fragile economy after the most destructive wildfires in its history erupted six months ago. Now, immigration raids are driving workers crucial to the rebuilding into the shadows.
item.dc:creator: John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: An employee at a car wash closed due to a recent ICE raid in Westchester, California, on June 11, 2025.

item.title: Carney Says New Oil Pipeline Proposal ‘Highly Likely’ in Canada
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said a new oil pipeline to Canada’s West Coast is “highly likely” to be proposed as a nation-building project, which could mean it becomes part of Ottawa’s push to fast-track major developments under new legislation.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, speaks at LeBreton Flats on Canada Day in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Canada Day, which has been celebrated since 1868, also coincides this year with the 60th anniversary of the Canadian flag.

item.title: Suriname’s New Leader Vows to Make Oil Wealth ‘Available to All’
item.description: Suriname officially elected its first female president as the small, Dutch-speaking nation on the Caribbean coast of South America prepares to navigate an oil boom.
item.dc:creator: Denis Chabrol

media:content.media:description: Jennifer Geerlings-Simons speaks to lawmakers in Paramaribo, Suriname, on June 29.

item.title: BRICS Leaders Condemn Attacks on Iran, Tell Israel to Leave Gaza
item.description: BRICS leaders condemned US and Israeli attacks on Iran and called on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to withdraw troops from the Gaza Strip, urging “just and lasting” solutions to conflicts across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, S'thembile Cele, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, center, speaks during the BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro on July 6.

item.title: Texas Flood Deaths Rise as Crews Seek Victims in Grid Search
item.description: At least 70 people have died and many children are missing in the Texas Hill Country after catastrophic flooding that left officials struggling to explain whether they did enough to warn people of the fast-rising waters.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: Overturned vehicles and broken trees after flooding caused by a flash flood at the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas, on July 5.
